t: Ecclesiastes 1
Everything Is Futile
The*p words of the Teacher, son of David, king in Jerusalem.
“Absolute*pn futility,” says the Teacher. “Absolute*ln futility. Everything is futile.”
What*ln does a person gain for all his efforts that*ln he labors at under the sun?
A*ln generation goes and a generation comes, but*ln the earth remains forever.
The*ln sun rises and the sun sets; panting,*ln it hurries back to the place where*ln it rises.
Gusting*ln to the south, turning*ln to the north, turning,*ln turning, goes the wind, and*ln the wind returns in its cycles.
All*ln the streams flow to the sea, yet*ln the sea is never full; to*ln the place where the streams flow, there*ln they flow again.
All*ln things are wearisome, more*ln than anyone can say. The*ln eye is not satisfied by seeing or*ln the ear filled with hearing.
What*ln has been is what will be, and*ln what has been done is what will be done; there*ln is nothing new under the sun.
Can*ln one say about anything, “Look,*ln this is new”? It*ln has already existed in the ages before us.
There*ln is no remembrance of those who came before; and*ln of those who will come after there*ln will also be no remembrance by*ln those who follow them.
The Limitations of Wisdom
I,*p the Teacher, have been king over Israel in Jerusalem.
I applied my mind to examine and explore through wisdom all that is done under heaven. God has given people this miserable task to keep them occupied.
I have seen all the things that are done under the sun and have found everything to be futile, a pursuit of the wind.
What*pn is crooked cannot be straightened; what*ln is lacking cannot be counted.
I*p said to myself, “See, I have amassed wisdom far beyond all those who were over Jerusalem before me, and my mind has thoroughly grasped wisdom and knowledge.”
I applied my mind to know wisdom and knowledge, madness and folly; I learned that this too is a pursuit of the wind.
For*pn with much wisdom is much sorrow; as*ln knowledge increases, grief increases.
